Fam. xv. 3 [22 February 1353] .

PAGE 90. Zanobi da Strada was another of the friends Petrarch made at Florence in 1350. He was a schoolmaster, scholar, and poet.

Petrarch held that men of letters should be disinterested in their pursuit of knowledge, and further that to extend the sphere of knowledge was a higher duty than that of instruction (cf. Benetti-Brunelli, Le origini ital. d. scuola umanistica, pp. 48, 49, and 175). Therefore in 1352 he advised Zanobi to abandon the profession of schoolmaster and go to Naples under the patronage of Niccolo Acciaiuoli. There is a difficulty, at present un- solved, as to this date 1352 and the date of the present letter. F. Forcellini, in an article in ‘ Archiv. stor. Nap.' 1912, p. 242, seq. produces'a document, dated November 1349, showing that Zanobi was already in Naples at that date. Forcellini therefore assigns the present letter and several others to 1349. But the letters were written from Avignon and the internal evidence shows that that address is not a later addition. F orcellini’s argument that the internal evidence proves that these letters were written in Gallia Cisalpina is founded on a mistranslation by F racassetti. In 1355 by the influence of Acciaiuoli Zanobi receivednst—hnep-th'ss‘ laurel wreath from the Emperor Charles IV, during his visit to Italy. Petrarch was by no means pleased at this rivalry, Q remained on friendly terms with Zanobi, and in 1359 helped him to obtain the post of papal secretary. Petrareh's dis· pleasure was shared by his friends 3 they knew Zanobi's limitations. Cf. R. Renier, Liriche . . . di Fazio degli Uberti, Florence, 1883, p. ccv, note. Zanobi died in 1361.
